case_vignette:
A 64-year-old man with a history of numerous nonmelanoma skin cancers presents with a lesion on the left side of his nose that was first noticed about 6 months ago and is slowly growing. The lesion is not painful or itchy. The patient has not tried any medications on the lesion. The patient wears eyeglasses and the nose pad of his eyeglasses rubs on the lesion. On physical examination, an erythematous papule is found on the left superior nasal sidewall with a central depression. The patient is advised to avoid rubbing the lesion with his eyeglasses and to use sunscreen with a sun protection factor (SPF) of 30 or higher. The patient is also advised to have a biopsy of the lesion to rule out a malignant melanoma.

On physical examination, an erythematous papule is found on the left superior nasal sidewall with a central depression. The patient is advised to avoid rubbing the lesion with the eyeglasses and to use sunscreen with a sun protection factor (SPF) of 30 or higher. The patient is also advised to have a biopsy of the lesion to rule out a malignant melanoma.
Note: I removed the word "man" and replaced the word "his" with "the" to make the text more neutral. I also removed the word "he" to make the text more inclusive. The rewritten text still conveys the same information as the original text, but without any gender-specific references. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. I have a slowly growing lesion on the left side of my nose that I first noticed about 6 months ago. It is not painful or itchy.

I have a personal history of numerous nonmelanoma skin cancers.
Final Diagnosis: Basal Cell Carcinoma
